thread.title: Shares on Track for Third Week of Gains as Oil Tries to Rebound
thread.title_full: Shares on Track for Third Week of Gains as Oil Tries to Rebound - Bloomberg Business

author: Bloomberg.com
title: Shares on Track for Third Week of Gains as Oil Tries to Rebound
text:
Stocks looked set to round out another week of gains, with most Asian index futures rising following a bounce back in the U.S. as bets on the Federal Reserve raising interest rates this year languish around 30 percent. Oil rose for the first time this week.
Australian shares climbed a second day, while futures on Asian indexes except Hong Kong signaled gains after an advance in banking stocks sent the Standard & Poor’s 500 Index to an eight-week high. Despite rallying Thursday, the greenback is on track for a third straight weekly decline amid speculation below-estimate data on major economies will prompt central bankers to maintain current stimulus levels at least through the end of the year. New Zealand’s currency fell as inflation came in below the central bank’s target band. U.S. oil snapped its slump but remained below $47 a barrel.
The October rally in stocks, briefly interrupted this week, has been accompanied by a pull back in the greenback
“The Fed is the 800-pound gorilla,” said Michael Antonelli, an institutional equity sales trader and managing director at Robert W. Baird & Co. in Milwaukee. “People’s expectations around what they’re doing are what cause sharp reversals or sharp gains.
A steeper-than-expected increase in U.S. consumer prices Thursday failed to bolster odds on the Fed raising borrowing costs before the year is out, with data on major economies around the world trailing analysts’ estimates by the most in four months. Traders are betting that ongoing uncertainty over the global outlook will stay the Fed’s hand until 2016 and that policy makers from Europe to Asia will keep on pumping out what is in some places a record level of stimulus. Global stocks are headed for a third straight weekly advance amid demand for high-yielding and emerging-market assets.
Stocks
The S&P/ASX 200 Index rose 0.8 percent by 10:29 a.m. in Sydney, and New Zealand’s S&P/ NZX 50 Index extended gains into a sixth straight day. Futures on the S&P 500 were up 0.1 percent after better-then-estimated earnings from Citigroup Inc. helped drive a 1.5 percent rebound in the U.S. benchmark following a two-day drop.
The probability of a Fed interest-rate increase by the central bank’s December policy meeting has dropped to 30 percent, down from 70 percent at the start of August, according to futures data compiled by Bloomberg.
“The tepidness of the data is giving the market a chance to reinstate long positions,” Evan Lucas, a markets strategist in Melbourne at IG Ltd., said in an e-mail to clients.
Futures on Japan’s Nikkei 225 Stock Average were bid up 0.3 percent in the Osaka pre-market, at 18,260, with the country’s broader Topix index down 1.6 percent in the holiday-shortened week despite rallying 1.4 percent on Thursday. Yen-denominated Nikkei futures added 0.2 percent in Chicago to 18,245. Contracts on the Kospi index in Seoul rose 0.1 percent.
The picture was more mixed for China, with futures on the Hang Seng China Enterprises Index, which tracks mainland shares listed in Hong Kong, falling less than 0.1 percent in most recent trading, while those on the FTSE China A50 Index jumped 1.2 percent. The largest U.S. exchange-traded fund tracking Chinese stocks soared 4.7 percent in New York Thursday, the most in a month.
The Reserve Bank of Australia issues a report on financial stability Friday.
